doc.title: EMBOSS

description.text: European Molecular Biology Open Software Suite

doc.reference: EMBOSS: The European Molecular Biology Open Software Suite (2000) Rice,P. Longden,I. and Bleasby, A. Trends in Genetics 16, (6) pp276--277

description.text: Displays sequences with features in pretty format

fieldset.title: This parameter is mandatory
fieldset.data-formats: EMBL FASTA GCG GENBANK NBRF CODATA RAW SWISSPROT GFF

xhtml:div.label: Things to display Enter your own list of things to display Sequence only Default sequence with features Pretty sequence One frame translation Three frame translations Six frame translations Restriction enzyme map Baroque

Specify your own things to display (value from 1 to 100)?
Specify a list of one or more code characters in the order in which you wish things to be displayed one above the other down the page.
S: Sequence
B: Blank line
1: Frame1 translation
2: Frame2 translation
3: Frame3 translation
-1: Compframe1 translation
-2: Compframe2 translation
-3: Compframe3 translation
T: Ticks line
N: Number ticks line
C: Complement sequence
F: Features
R: Restriction enzyme cut sites in forward sense
-R: Restriction enzyme cut sites in reverse sense
A: Annotation
For example if you wish to see things displayed in the order: sequence, complement sequence, ticks line, frame 1 translation, blank line; then you should enter 'S,C,T,1,B'.

Regions to translate (eg: 4-57,78-94)?
Regions to translate (if translating). If this is left blank the complete sequence is translated. A set of regions is specified by a set of pairs of positions. The positions are integers. They are separated by any non-digit, non-alpha character. Examples of region specifications are: 24-45, 56-78 1:45, 67=99;765..888

Regions to translate in reverse direction (eg: 78-94,4-57)?
Regions to translate (if translating). If this is left blank the complete sequence is translated. A set of regions is specified by a set of pairs of positions. The positions are integers. They are separated by any non-digit, non-alpha character. Examples of region specifications are: 78-56, 45-24, 888..765, 99=67; 45:1

Regions to put in uppercase (eg: 4-57,78-94)?
Regions to put in uppercase. If this is left blank, then the sequence case is left alone. A set of regions is specified by a set of pairs of positions. The positions are integers. They are separated by any non-digit, non-alpha character. Examples of region specifications are: 24-45, 56-78 1:45, 67=99;765..888 1,5,8,10,23,45,57,99

Regions to colour in html (eg: 4-57 red 78-94 green)?
Regions to colour if formatting for HTML. If this is left blank, then the sequence is left alone. A set of regions is specified by a set of pairs of positions. The positions are integers. They are followed by any valid HTML font colour. Examples of region specifications are: 24-45 blue 56-78 orange 1-100 green 120-156 red A file of ranges to colour (one range per line) can be specified as '@filename'.

Regions to mark (eg: 4-57 promoter region 78-94 first exon)?
Regions to annotate by marking. If this is left blank, then no annotation is added. A set of regions is specified by a set of pairs of positions followed by optional text. The positions are integers. They are followed by any text (but not digits when on the command-line). Examples of region specifications are: 24-45 new domain 56-78 match to Mouse 1-100 First part 120-156 oligo A file of ranges to annotate (one range per line) can be specified as '@filename'.

Comma separated restriction enzyme list?
The name 'all' reads in all enzyme names from the REBASE database. You can specify enzymes by giving their names with commas between then, such as: 'HincII,hinfI,ppiI,hindiii'. The case of the names is not important. You can specify a file of enzyme names to read in by giving the name of the file holding the enzyme names with a '@' character in front of it, for example, '@enz.list'. Blank lines and lines starting with a hash character or '!' are ignored and all other lines are concatenated together with a comma character ',' and then treated as the list of enzymes to search for. An example of a file of enzyme names is: ! my enzymes HincII, ppiII ! other enzymes hindiii HinfI PpiI

Genetic codes Standard Standard (with alternative initiation codons) Vertebrate mitochondrial Yeast mitochondrial Mold, protozoan, coelenterate mitochondrial and mycoplasma/spiroplasma Invertebrate mitochondrial Ciliate macronuclear and dasycladacean Echinoderm mitochondrial Euplotid nuclear Bacterial Alternative yeast nuclear Ascidian mitochondrial Flatworm mitochondrial Blepharisma macronuclear Chlorophycean mitochondrial Trematode mitochondrial Scenedesmus obliquus Thraustochytrium mitochondrial

Source of feature to display?
By default any feature source in the feature table is shown. You can set this to match any feature source you wish to show. The source name is usually either the name of the program that detected the feature or it is the feature table (eg: EMBL) that the feature came from. The source may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to show more than one source, separate their names with the character '|', eg: gene* | embl

Type of feature to display?
By default any feature type in the feature table is shown. You can set this to match any feature type you wish to show. See http://www.ebi.ac.uk/embl/WebFeat/ for a list of the EMBL feature types and see Appendix A of the Swissprot user manual in http://www.expasy.org/sprot/userman.html for a list of the Swissprot feature types. The type may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to show more than one type, separate their names with the character '|', eg: *UTR | intron

Sense of feature to display (value from -1 to 1)?
By default any feature type in the feature table is shown. You can set this to match any feature sense you wish to show. 0 - any sense, 1 - forward sense, -1 - reverse sense

Minimum score of feature to display?
Minimum score of feature to display (see also maxscore)

Maximum score of feature to display?
Maximum score of feature to display. If both minscore and maxscore are zero (the default), then any score is ignored

Tag of feature to display?
Tags are the types of extra values that a feature may have. For example in the EMBL feature table, a 'CDS' type of feature may have the tags '/codon', '/codon_start', '/db_xref', '/EC_number', '/evidence', '/exception', '/function', '/gene', '/label', '/map', '/note', '/number', '/partial', '/product', '/protein_id', '/pseudo', '/standard_name', '/translation', '/transl_except', '/transl_table', or '/usedin'. Some of these tags also have values, for example '/gene' can have the value of the gene name. By default any feature tag in the feature table is shown. You can set this to match any feature tag you wish to show. The tag may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to show more than one tag, separate their names with the character '|', eg: gene | label

Value of feature tags to display?
Tag values are the values associated with a feature tag. Tags are the types of extra values that a feature may have. For example in the EMBL feature table, a 'CDS' type of feature may have the tags '/codon', '/codon_start', '/db_xref', '/EC_number', '/evidence', '/exception', '/function', '/gene', '/label', '/map', '/note', '/number', '/partial', '/product', '/protein_id', '/pseudo', '/standard_name', '/translation', '/transl_except', '/transl_table', or '/usedin'. Only some of these tags can have values, for example '/gene' can have the value of the gene name. By default any feature tag value in the feature table is shown. You can set this to match any feature tag value you wish to show. The tag value may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to show more than one tag value, separate their names with the character '|', eg: pax* | 10

Only display the matching tags?
Yes No
By default if any tag/value pair in a feature matches the specified tag and value, then all the tags/value pairs of that feature will be displayed. If this is set to be true, then only those tag/value pairs in a feature that match the specified tag and value will be displayed.

Display re sites in flat format?
Yes No
This changes the output format to one where the recognition site is indicated by a row of '===' characters and the cut site is pointed to by a '>' character in the forward sense, or a '<' in the reverse sense strand.

Minimum cuts per re (value from 1 to 1000)?
This sets the minimum number of cuts for any restriction enzyme that will be considered. Any enzymes that cut fewer times than this will be ignored.

Maximum cuts per re?
This sets the maximum number of cuts for any restriction enzyme that will be considered. Any enzymes that cut more times than this will be ignored.

Minimum recognition site length (value from 2 to 20)?
This sets the minimum length of the restriction enzyme recognition site. Any enzymes with sites shorter than this will be ignored.

Force single re site only cuts?
Yes No
If this is set then this forces the values of the mincuts and maxcuts qualifiers to both be 1. Any other value you may have set them to will be ignored.

Allow blunt end re cutters?
Yes No
This allows those enzymes which cut at the same position on the forward and reverse strands to be considered.

Allow sticky end re cutters?
Yes No
This allows those enzymes which cut at different positions on the forward and reverse strands, leaving an overhang, to be considered.

Allow ambiguous re matches?
Yes No
This allows those enzymes which have one or more 'N' ambiguity codes in their pattern to be considered

Allow circular dna?
Yes No
If this is set then this allows searches for restriction enzyme recognition site and cut positions that span the end of the sequence to be considered.

Use methylation data?
Yes No
If this is set then RE recognition sites will not match methylated bases.

Only use restriction enzymes with suppliers?
Yes No
If this is set, then only those enzymes with a commercial supplier will be searched for. This qualifier is ignored if you have specified an explicit list of enzymes to search for, rather than searching through 'all' the enzymes in the REBASE database. It is assumed that, if you are asking for an explicit enzyme, then you probably know where to get it from and so all enzymes names that you have asked to be searched for, and which cut, will be reported whether or not they have a commercial supplier.

Limits re hits to one isoschizomer?
Yes No
This limits the reporting of enzymes to just one enzyme from each group of isoschizomers. The enzyme chosen to represent an isoschizomer group is the prototype indicated in the data file 'embossre.equ', which is created by the program 'rebaseextract'. If you prefer different prototypes to be used, make a copy of embossre.equ in your home directory and edit it. If this value is set to be false then all of the input enzymes will be reported. You might like to set this to false if you are supplying an explicit set of enzymes rather than searching 'all' of them.

Minimum size of orfs (value greater than or equal to 0)?
This sets the minimum size of Open Reading Frames (ORFs) to display in the translations. All other translation regions are masked by changing the amino acids to '-' characters.
Display protein sequences in three-letter code Yes No
Number the sequences Yes No
Width of sequence to display (value greater than or equal to 1)
Line length of page (0 for indefinite) (value greater than or equal to 0)
Margin around sequence for numbering (value greater than or equal to 0)

Show sequence id?
Yes No
Set this to be false if you do not wish to display the ID name of the sequence

Show description?
Yes No
Set this to be false if you do not wish to display the description of the sequence
Offset to start numbering the sequence from
Use html formatting Yes No
Name of the output file (e_outfile)

div.title: This parameter is mandatory
div.data-formats: EMBL FASTA GCG GENBANK NBRF CODATA RAW SWISSPROT GFF

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Specify a list of one or more code characters in the order in which you wish things to be displayed one above the other down the page.
S: Sequence
B: Blank line
1: Frame1 translation
2: Frame2 translation
3: Frame3 translation
-1: Compframe1 translation
-2: Compframe2 translation
-3: Compframe3 translation
T: Ticks line
N: Number ticks line
C: Complement sequence
F: Features
R: Restriction enzyme cut sites in forward sense
-R: Restriction enzyme cut sites in reverse sense
A: Annotation
For example if you wish to see things displayed in the order: sequence, complement sequence, ticks line, frame 1 translation, blank line; then you should enter 'S,C,T,1,B'.

Regions to translate (if translating). If this is left blank the complete sequence is translated. A set of regions is specified by a set of pairs of positions. The positions are integers. They are separated by any non-digit, non-alpha character. Examples of region specifications are: 24-45, 56-78 1:45, 67=99;765..888

Regions to translate (if translating). If this is left blank the complete sequence is translated. A set of regions is specified by a set of pairs of positions. The positions are integers. They are separated by any non-digit, non-alpha character. Examples of region specifications are: 78-56, 45-24, 888..765, 99=67; 45:1

Regions to put in uppercase. If this is left blank, then the sequence case is left alone. A set of regions is specified by a set of pairs of positions. The positions are integers. They are separated by any non-digit, non-alpha character. Examples of region specifications are: 24-45, 56-78 1:45, 67=99;765..888 1,5,8,10,23,45,57,99

Regions to colour if formatting for HTML. If this is left blank, then the sequence is left alone. A set of regions is specified by a set of pairs of positions. The positions are integers. They are followed by any valid HTML font colour. Examples of region specifications are: 24-45 blue 56-78 orange 1-100 green 120-156 red A file of ranges to colour (one range per line) can be specified as '@filename'.

Regions to annotate by marking. If this is left blank, then no annotation is added. A set of regions is specified by a set of pairs of positions followed by optional text. The positions are integers. They are followed by any text (but not digits when on the command-line). Examples of region specifications are: 24-45 new domain 56-78 match to Mouse 1-100 First part 120-156 oligo A file of ranges to annotate (one range per line) can be specified as '@filename'.

The name 'all' reads in all enzyme names from the REBASE database. You can specify enzymes by giving their names with commas between then, such as: 'HincII,hinfI,ppiI,hindiii'. The case of the names is not important. You can specify a file of enzyme names to read in by giving the name of the file holding the enzyme names with a '@' character in front of it, for example, '@enz.list'. Blank lines and lines starting with a hash character or '!' are ignored and all other lines are concatenated together with a comma character ',' and then treated as the list of enzymes to search for. An example of a file of enzyme names is: ! my enzymes HincII, ppiII ! other enzymes hindiii HinfI PpiI

By default any feature source in the feature table is shown. You can set this to match any feature source you wish to show. The source name is usually either the name of the program that detected the feature or it is the feature table (eg: EMBL) that the feature came from. The source may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to show more than one source, separate their names with the character '|', eg: gene* | embl

By default any feature type in the feature table is shown. You can set this to match any feature type you wish to show. See http://www.ebi.ac.uk/embl/WebFeat/ for a list of the EMBL feature types and see Appendix A of the Swissprot user manual in http://www.expasy.org/sprot/userman.html for a list of the Swissprot feature types. The type may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to show more than one type, separate their names with the character '|', eg: *UTR | intron
By default any feature type in the feature table is shown. You can set this to match any feature sense you wish to show. 0 - any sense, 1 - forward sense, -1 - reverse sense
Minimum score of feature to display (see also maxscore)
Maximum score of feature to display. If both minscore and maxscore are zero (the default), then any score is ignored

Tags are the types of extra values that a feature may have. For example in the EMBL feature table, a 'CDS' type of feature may have the tags '/codon', '/codon_start', '/db_xref', '/EC_number', '/evidence', '/exception', '/function', '/gene', '/label', '/map', '/note', '/number', '/partial', '/product', '/protein_id', '/pseudo', '/standard_name', '/translation', '/transl_except', '/transl_table', or '/usedin'. Some of these tags also have values, for example '/gene' can have the value of the gene name. By default any feature tag in the feature table is shown. You can set this to match any feature tag you wish to show. The tag may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to show more than one tag, separate their names with the character '|', eg: gene | label

Tag values are the values associated with a feature tag. Tags are the types of extra values that a feature may have. For example in the EMBL feature table, a 'CDS' type of feature may have the tags '/codon', '/codon_start', '/db_xref', '/EC_number', '/evidence', '/exception', '/function', '/gene', '/label', '/map', '/note', '/number', '/partial', '/product', '/protein_id', '/pseudo', '/standard_name', '/translation', '/transl_except', '/transl_table', or '/usedin'. Only some of these tags can have values, for example '/gene' can have the value of the gene name. By default any feature tag value in the feature table is shown. You can set this to match any feature tag value you wish to show. The tag value may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to show more than one tag value, separate their names with the character '|', eg: pax* | 10

By default if any tag/value pair in a feature matches the specified tag and value, then all the tags/value pairs of that feature will be displayed. If this is set to be true, then only those tag/value pairs in a feature that match the specified tag and value will be displayed.

This changes the output format to one where the recognition site is indicated by a row of '===' characters and the cut site is pointed to by a '>' character in the forward sense, or a '<' in the reverse sense strand.
This sets the minimum number of cuts for any restriction enzyme that will be considered. Any enzymes that cut fewer times than this will be ignored.
This sets the maximum number of cuts for any restriction enzyme that will be considered. Any enzymes that cut more times than this will be ignored.
This sets the minimum length of the restriction enzyme recognition site. Any enzymes with sites shorter than this will be ignored.
If this is set then this forces the values of the mincuts and maxcuts qualifiers to both be 1. Any other value you may have set them to will be ignored.
This allows those enzymes which cut at the same position on the forward and reverse strands to be considered.
This allows those enzymes which cut at different positions on the forward and reverse strands, leaving an overhang, to be considered.
This allows those enzymes which have one or more 'N' ambiguity codes in their pattern to be considered
If this is set then this allows searches for restriction enzyme recognition site and cut positions that span the end of the sequence to be considered.
If this is set then RE recognition sites will not match methylated bases.

If this is set, then only those enzymes with a commercial supplier will be searched for. This qualifier is ignored if you have specified an explicit list of enzymes to search for, rather than searching through 'all' the enzymes in the REBASE database. It is assumed that, if you are asking for an explicit enzyme, then you probably know where to get it from and so all enzymes names that you have asked to be searched for, and which cut, will be reported whether or not they have a commercial supplier.

This limits the reporting of enzymes to just one enzyme from each group of isoschizomers. The enzyme chosen to represent an isoschizomer group is the prototype indicated in the data file 'embossre.equ', which is created by the program 'rebaseextract'. If you prefer different prototypes to be used, make a copy of embossre.equ in your home directory and edit it. If this value is set to be false then all of the input enzymes will be reported. You might like to set this to false if you are supplying an explicit set of enzymes rather than searching 'all' of them.
This sets the minimum size of Open Reading Frames (ORFs) to display in the translations. All other translation regions are masked by changing the amino acids to '-' characters.
Set this to be false if you do not wish to display the ID name of the sequence
Set this to be false if you do not wish to display the description of the sequence

div.title: This parameter is mandatory
div.data-formats: EMBL FASTA GCG GENBANK NBRF CODATA RAW SWISSPROT GFF

velem.label: Enter your own list of things to display

format.code: ("", " -format=" + str(value))[value is not None and value!=vdef]

interface.label: Things to display Enter your own list of things to display Sequence only Default sequence with features Pretty sequence One frame translation Three frame translations Six frame translations Restriction enzyme map Baroque

parameter.name: e_things
parameter.prompt: Specify your own things to display (value from 1 to 100)

format.code: ("", " -things=" + str(value))[value is not None and value!=vdef]

comment.text: Specify a list of one or more code characters in the order in which you wish things to be displayed one above the other down the page.
S: Sequence
B: Blank line
1: Frame1 translation
2: Frame2 translation
3: Frame3 translation
-1: Compframe1 translation
-2: Compframe2 translation
-3: Compframe3 translation
T: Ticks line
N: Number ticks line
C: Complement sequence
F: Features
R: Restriction enzyme cut sites in forward sense
-R: Restriction enzyme cut sites in reverse sense
A: Annotation
For example if you wish to see things displayed in the order: sequence, complement sequence, ticks line, frame 1 translation, blank line; then you should enter 'S,C,T,1,B'.

format.code: ("", " -enzymes=" + str(value))[value is not None and value!=vdef]

comment.text: The name 'all' reads in all enzyme names from the REBASE database. You can specify enzymes by giving their names with commas between then, such as: 'HincII,hinfI,ppiI,hindiii'. The case of the names is not important. You can specify a file of enzyme names to read in by giving the name of the file holding the enzyme names with a '@' character in front of it, for example, '@enz.list'. Blank lines and lines starting with a hash character or '!' are ignored and all other lines are concatenated together with a comma character ',' and then treated as the list of enzymes to search for. An example of a file of enzyme names is: ! my enzymes HincII, ppiII ! other enzymes hindiii HinfI PpiI

interface.label:
Comma separated restriction enzyme list?
The name 'all' reads in all enzyme names from the REBASE database. You can specify enzymes by giving their names with commas between then, such as: 'HincII,hinfI,ppiI,hindiii'. The case of the names is not important. You can specify a file of enzyme names to read in by giving the name of the file holding the enzyme names with a '@' character in front of it, for example, '@enz.list'. Blank lines and lines starting with a hash character or '!' are ignored and all other lines are concatenated together with a comma character ',' and then treated as the list of enzymes to search for. An example of a file of enzyme names is: ! my enzymes HincII, ppiII ! other enzymes hindiii HinfI PpiI

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: The name 'all' reads in all enzyme names from the REBASE database. You can specify enzymes by giving their names with commas between then, such as: 'HincII,hinfI,ppiI,hindiii'. The case of the names is not important. You can specify a file of enzyme names to read in by giving the name of the file holding the enzyme names with a '@' character in front of it, for example, '@enz.list'. Blank lines and lines starting with a hash character or '!' are ignored and all other lines are concatenated together with a comma character ',' and then treated as the list of enzymes to search for. An example of a file of enzyme names is: ! my enzymes HincII, ppiII ! other enzymes hindiii HinfI PpiI

velem.label: Mold, protozoan, coelenterate mitochondrial and mycoplasma/spiroplasma

format.code: ("", " -table=" + str(value))[value is not None and value!=vdef]

interface.label: Genetic codes Standard Standard (with alternative initiation codons) Vertebrate mitochondrial Yeast mitochondrial Mold, protozoan, coelenterate mitochondrial and mycoplasma/spiroplasma Invertebrate mitochondrial Ciliate macronuclear and dasycladacean Echinoderm mitochondrial Euplotid nuclear Bacterial Alternative yeast nuclear Ascidian mitochondrial Flatworm mitochondrial Blepharisma macronuclear Chlorophycean mitochondrial Trematode mitochondrial Scenedesmus obliquus Thraustochytrium mitochondrial

comment.text: By default any feature source in the feature table is shown. You can set this to match any feature source you wish to show. The source name is usually either the name of the program that detected the feature or it is the feature table (eg: EMBL) that the feature came from. The source may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to show more than one source, separate their names with the character '|', eg: gene* | embl

interface.label:
Source of feature to display?
By default any feature source in the feature table is shown. You can set this to match any feature source you wish to show. The source name is usually either the name of the program that detected the feature or it is the feature table (eg: EMBL) that the feature came from. The source may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to show more than one source, separate their names with the character '|', eg: gene* | embl

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: By default any feature source in the feature table is shown. You can set this to match any feature source you wish to show. The source name is usually either the name of the program that detected the feature or it is the feature table (eg: EMBL) that the feature came from. The source may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to show more than one source, separate their names with the character '|', eg: gene* | embl

comment.text: By default any feature type in the feature table is shown. You can set this to match any feature type you wish to show. See http://www.ebi.ac.uk/embl/WebFeat/ for a list of the EMBL feature types and see Appendix A of the Swissprot user manual in http://www.expasy.org/sprot/userman.html for a list of the Swissprot feature types. The type may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to show more than one type, separate their names with the character '|', eg: *UTR | intron

interface.label:
Type of feature to display?
By default any feature type in the feature table is shown. You can set this to match any feature type you wish to show. See http://www.ebi.ac.uk/embl/WebFeat/ for a list of the EMBL feature types and see Appendix A of the Swissprot user manual in http://www.expasy.org/sprot/userman.html for a list of the Swissprot feature types. The type may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to show more than one type, separate their names with the character '|', eg: *UTR | intron

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: By default any feature type in the feature table is shown. You can set this to match any feature type you wish to show. See http://www.ebi.ac.uk/embl/WebFeat/ for a list of the EMBL feature types and see Appendix A of the Swissprot user manual in http://www.expasy.org/sprot/userman.html for a list of the Swissprot feature types. The type may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to show more than one type, separate their names with the character '|', eg: *UTR | intron

parameter.name: e_sensematch
parameter.prompt: Sense of feature to display (value from -1 to 1)

format.code: ("", " -sensematch=" + str(value))[value is not None and value!=vdef]

message.text: Value greater than or equal to -1 is required
Value less than or equal to 1 is required

comment.text: By default any feature type in the feature table is shown. You can set this to match any feature sense you wish to show. 0 - any sense, 1 - forward sense, -1 - reverse sense

interface.label:
Sense of feature to display (value from -1 to 1)?
By default any feature type in the feature table is shown. You can set this to match any feature sense you wish to show. 0 - any sense, 1 - forward sense, -1 - reverse sense

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: By default any feature type in the feature table is shown. You can set this to match any feature sense you wish to show. 0 - any sense, 1 - forward sense, -1 - reverse sense

parameter.name: e_minscore
parameter.prompt: Minimum score of feature to display

format.code: ("", " -minscore=" + str(value))[value is not None and value!=vdef]

comment.text: Minimum score of feature to display (see also maxscore)

interface.label:
Minimum score of feature to display?
Minimum score of feature to display (see also maxscore)

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Minimum score of feature to display (see also maxscore)

parameter.name: e_maxscore
parameter.prompt: Maximum score of feature to display

format.code: ("", " -maxscore=" + str(value))[value is not None and value!=vdef]

comment.text: Maximum score of feature to display. If both minscore and maxscore are zero (the default), then any score is ignored

interface.label:
Maximum score of feature to display?
Maximum score of feature to display. If both minscore and maxscore are zero (the default), then any score is ignored

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Maximum score of feature to display. If both minscore and maxscore are zero (the default), then any score is ignored

comment.text: Tags are the types of extra values that a feature may have. For example in the EMBL feature table, a 'CDS' type of feature may have the tags '/codon', '/codon_start', '/db_xref', '/EC_number', '/evidence', '/exception', '/function', '/gene', '/label', '/map', '/note', '/number', '/partial', '/product', '/protein_id', '/pseudo', '/standard_name', '/translation', '/transl_except', '/transl_table', or '/usedin'. Some of these tags also have values, for example '/gene' can have the value of the gene name. By default any feature tag in the feature table is shown. You can set this to match any feature tag you wish to show. The tag may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to show more than one tag, separate their names with the character '|', eg: gene | label

interface.label:
Tag of feature to display?
Tags are the types of extra values that a feature may have. For example in the EMBL feature table, a 'CDS' type of feature may have the tags '/codon', '/codon_start', '/db_xref', '/EC_number', '/evidence', '/exception', '/function', '/gene', '/label', '/map', '/note', '/number', '/partial', '/product', '/protein_id', '/pseudo', '/standard_name', '/translation', '/transl_except', '/transl_table', or '/usedin'. Some of these tags also have values, for example '/gene' can have the value of the gene name. By default any feature tag in the feature table is shown. You can set this to match any feature tag you wish to show. The tag may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to show more than one tag, separate their names with the character '|', eg: gene | label

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Tags are the types of extra values that a feature may have. For example in the EMBL feature table, a 'CDS' type of feature may have the tags '/codon', '/codon_start', '/db_xref', '/EC_number', '/evidence', '/exception', '/function', '/gene', '/label', '/map', '/note', '/number', '/partial', '/product', '/protein_id', '/pseudo', '/standard_name', '/translation', '/transl_except', '/transl_table', or '/usedin'. Some of these tags also have values, for example '/gene' can have the value of the gene name. By default any feature tag in the feature table is shown. You can set this to match any feature tag you wish to show. The tag may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to show more than one tag, separate their names with the character '|', eg: gene | label

parameter.name: e_valuematch
parameter.prompt: Value of feature tags to display

comment.text: Tag values are the values associated with a feature tag. Tags are the types of extra values that a feature may have. For example in the EMBL feature table, a 'CDS' type of feature may have the tags '/codon', '/codon_start', '/db_xref', '/EC_number', '/evidence', '/exception', '/function', '/gene', '/label', '/map', '/note', '/number', '/partial', '/product', '/protein_id', '/pseudo', '/standard_name', '/translation', '/transl_except', '/transl_table', or '/usedin'. Only some of these tags can have values, for example '/gene' can have the value of the gene name. By default any feature tag value in the feature table is shown. You can set this to match any feature tag value you wish to show. The tag value may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to show more than one tag value, separate their names with the character '|', eg: pax* | 10

interface.label:
Value of feature tags to display?
Tag values are the values associated with a feature tag. Tags are the types of extra values that a feature may have. For example in the EMBL feature table, a 'CDS' type of feature may have the tags '/codon', '/codon_start', '/db_xref', '/EC_number', '/evidence', '/exception', '/function', '/gene', '/label', '/map', '/note', '/number', '/partial', '/product', '/protein_id', '/pseudo', '/standard_name', '/translation', '/transl_except', '/transl_table', or '/usedin'. Only some of these tags can have values, for example '/gene' can have the value of the gene name. By default any feature tag value in the feature table is shown. You can set this to match any feature tag value you wish to show. The tag value may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to show more than one tag value, separate their names with the character '|', eg: pax* | 10

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: Tag values are the values associated with a feature tag. Tags are the types of extra values that a feature may have. For example in the EMBL feature table, a 'CDS' type of feature may have the tags '/codon', '/codon_start', '/db_xref', '/EC_number', '/evidence', '/exception', '/function', '/gene', '/label', '/map', '/note', '/number', '/partial', '/product', '/protein_id', '/pseudo', '/standard_name', '/translation', '/transl_except', '/transl_table', or '/usedin'. Only some of these tags can have values, for example '/gene' can have the value of the gene name. By default any feature tag value in the feature table is shown. You can set this to match any feature tag value you wish to show. The tag value may be wildcarded by using '*'. If you wish to show more than one tag value, separate their names with the character '|', eg: pax* | 10

comment.text: By default if any tag/value pair in a feature matches the specified tag and value, then all the tags/value pairs of that feature will be displayed. If this is set to be true, then only those tag/value pairs in a feature that match the specified tag and value will be displayed.

interface.label:
Only display the matching tags?
Yes No
By default if any tag/value pair in a feature matches the specified tag and value, then all the tags/value pairs of that feature will be displayed. If this is set to be true, then only those tag/value pairs in a feature that match the specified tag and value will be displayed.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: By default if any tag/value pair in a feature matches the specified tag and value, then all the tags/value pairs of that feature will be displayed. If this is set to be true, then only those tag/value pairs in a feature that match the specified tag and value will be displayed.

parameter.name: e_flatreformat
parameter.prompt: Display re sites in flat format

comment.text: This changes the output format to one where the recognition site is indicated by a row of '===' characters and the cut site is pointed to by a '>' character in the forward sense, or a '<' in the reverse sense strand.

interface.label:
Display re sites in flat format?
Yes No
This changes the output format to one where the recognition site is indicated by a row of '===' characters and the cut site is pointed to by a '>' character in the forward sense, or a '<' in the reverse sense strand.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This changes the output format to one where the recognition site is indicated by a row of '===' characters and the cut site is pointed to by a '>' character in the forward sense, or a '<' in the reverse sense strand.

parameter.name: e_mincuts
parameter.prompt: Minimum cuts per re (value from 1 to 1000)

format.code: ("", " -mincuts=" + str(value))[value is not None and value!=vdef]

message.text: Value greater than or equal to 1 is required
Value less than or equal to 1000 is required

comment.text: This sets the minimum number of cuts for any restriction enzyme that will be considered. Any enzymes that cut fewer times than this will be ignored.

interface.label:
Minimum cuts per re (value from 1 to 1000)?
This sets the minimum number of cuts for any restriction enzyme that will be considered. Any enzymes that cut fewer times than this will be ignored.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This sets the minimum number of cuts for any restriction enzyme that will be considered. Any enzymes that cut fewer times than this will be ignored.

format.code: ("", " -maxcuts=" + str(value))[value is not None and value!=vdef]

comment.text: This sets the maximum number of cuts for any restriction enzyme that will be considered. Any enzymes that cut more times than this will be ignored.

interface.label:
Maximum cuts per re?
This sets the maximum number of cuts for any restriction enzyme that will be considered. Any enzymes that cut more times than this will be ignored.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This sets the maximum number of cuts for any restriction enzyme that will be considered. Any enzymes that cut more times than this will be ignored.

parameter.name: e_sitelen
parameter.prompt: Minimum recognition site length (value from 2 to 20)

format.code: ("", " -sitelen=" + str(value))[value is not None and value!=vdef]

message.text: Value greater than or equal to 2 is required
Value less than or equal to 20 is required

comment.text: This sets the minimum length of the restriction enzyme recognition site. Any enzymes with sites shorter than this will be ignored.

interface.label:
Minimum recognition site length (value from 2 to 20)?
This sets the minimum length of the restriction enzyme recognition site. Any enzymes with sites shorter than this will be ignored.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This sets the minimum length of the restriction enzyme recognition site. Any enzymes with sites shorter than this will be ignored.

parameter.name: e_single
parameter.prompt: Force single re site only cuts

comment.text: If this is set then this forces the values of the mincuts and maxcuts qualifiers to both be 1. Any other value you may have set them to will be ignored.

interface.label:
Force single re site only cuts?
Yes No
If this is set then this forces the values of the mincuts and maxcuts qualifiers to both be 1. Any other value you may have set them to will be ignored.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: If this is set then this forces the values of the mincuts and maxcuts qualifiers to both be 1. Any other value you may have set them to will be ignored.

comment.text: This allows those enzymes which cut at the same position on the forward and reverse strands to be considered.

interface.label:
Allow blunt end re cutters?
Yes No
This allows those enzymes which cut at the same position on the forward and reverse strands to be considered.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This allows those enzymes which cut at the same position on the forward and reverse strands to be considered.

comment.text: This allows those enzymes which cut at different positions on the forward and reverse strands, leaving an overhang, to be considered.

interface.label:
Allow sticky end re cutters?
Yes No
This allows those enzymes which cut at different positions on the forward and reverse strands, leaving an overhang, to be considered.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This allows those enzymes which cut at different positions on the forward and reverse strands, leaving an overhang, to be considered.

comment.text: This allows those enzymes which have one or more 'N' ambiguity codes in their pattern to be considered

interface.label:
Allow ambiguous re matches?
Yes No
This allows those enzymes which have one or more 'N' ambiguity codes in their pattern to be considered

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This allows those enzymes which have one or more 'N' ambiguity codes in their pattern to be considered

comment.text: If this is set then this allows searches for restriction enzyme recognition site and cut positions that span the end of the sequence to be considered.

interface.label:
Allow circular dna?
Yes No
If this is set then this allows searches for restriction enzyme recognition site and cut positions that span the end of the sequence to be considered.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: If this is set then this allows searches for restriction enzyme recognition site and cut positions that span the end of the sequence to be considered.

comment.text: If this is set then RE recognition sites will not match methylated bases.

interface.label:
Use methylation data?
Yes No
If this is set then RE recognition sites will not match methylated bases.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: If this is set then RE recognition sites will not match methylated bases.

parameter.name: e_commercial
parameter.prompt: Only use restriction enzymes with suppliers

comment.text: If this is set, then only those enzymes with a commercial supplier will be searched for. This qualifier is ignored if you have specified an explicit list of enzymes to search for, rather than searching through 'all' the enzymes in the REBASE database. It is assumed that, if you are asking for an explicit enzyme, then you probably know where to get it from and so all enzymes names that you have asked to be searched for, and which cut, will be reported whether or not they have a commercial supplier.

interface.label:
Only use restriction enzymes with suppliers?
Yes No
If this is set, then only those enzymes with a commercial supplier will be searched for. This qualifier is ignored if you have specified an explicit list of enzymes to search for, rather than searching through 'all' the enzymes in the REBASE database. It is assumed that, if you are asking for an explicit enzyme, then you probably know where to get it from and so all enzymes names that you have asked to be searched for, and which cut, will be reported whether or not they have a commercial supplier.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: If this is set, then only those enzymes with a commercial supplier will be searched for. This qualifier is ignored if you have specified an explicit list of enzymes to search for, rather than searching through 'all' the enzymes in the REBASE database. It is assumed that, if you are asking for an explicit enzyme, then you probably know where to get it from and so all enzymes names that you have asked to be searched for, and which cut, will be reported whether or not they have a commercial supplier.

parameter.name: e_limit
parameter.prompt: Limits re hits to one isoschizomer

comment.text: This limits the reporting of enzymes to just one enzyme from each group of isoschizomers. The enzyme chosen to represent an isoschizomer group is the prototype indicated in the data file 'embossre.equ', which is created by the program 'rebaseextract'. If you prefer different prototypes to be used, make a copy of embossre.equ in your home directory and edit it. If this value is set to be false then all of the input enzymes will be reported. You might like to set this to false if you are supplying an explicit set of enzymes rather than searching 'all' of them.

interface.label:
Limits re hits to one isoschizomer?
Yes No
This limits the reporting of enzymes to just one enzyme from each group of isoschizomers. The enzyme chosen to represent an isoschizomer group is the prototype indicated in the data file 'embossre.equ', which is created by the program 'rebaseextract'. If you prefer different prototypes to be used, make a copy of embossre.equ in your home directory and edit it. If this value is set to be false then all of the input enzymes will be reported. You might like to set this to false if you are supplying an explicit set of enzymes rather than searching 'all' of them.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This limits the reporting of enzymes to just one enzyme from each group of isoschizomers. The enzyme chosen to represent an isoschizomer group is the prototype indicated in the data file 'embossre.equ', which is created by the program 'rebaseextract'. If you prefer different prototypes to be used, make a copy of embossre.equ in your home directory and edit it. If this value is set to be false then all of the input enzymes will be reported. You might like to set this to false if you are supplying an explicit set of enzymes rather than searching 'all' of them.

parameter.name: e_orfminsize
parameter.prompt: Minimum size of orfs (value greater than or equal to 0)

format.code: ("", " -orfminsize=" + str(value))[value is not None and value!=vdef]

message.text: Value greater than or equal to 0 is required

comment.text: This sets the minimum size of Open Reading Frames (ORFs) to display in the translations. All other translation regions are masked by changing the amino acids to '-' characters.

interface.label:
Minimum size of orfs (value greater than or equal to 0)?
This sets the minimum size of Open Reading Frames (ORFs) to display in the translations. All other translation regions are masked by changing the amino acids to '-' characters.

xhtml:div.xhtml:div: This sets the minimum size of Open Reading Frames (ORFs) to display in the translations. All other translation regions are masked by changing the amino acids to '-' characters.
